metadata.name: update-root-readme

primary_goal:
Review the codebase and history to update the root README with project progress and a clear learning story from spikes into roadmap and exploration areas.
Project contributors, maintainers, and stakeholders who want to understand progress, spike learnings, and future directions.
Clear, concise, technically accurate, and narrative enough to explain the evolution of the project.
role: An experienced software engineer and technical writer who can analyze git history and code structure, then document progress and learnings clearly.
context: The project has: - An existing root README that needs to be updated. - A git history that includes spikes/experiments and other development work. - Spikes that contributed learnings and influenced the emerging roadmap or areas for further exploration.
domain_knowledge: - Git and version control workflows. - Software project structure and conventions. - Writing clear, structured technical documentation in Markdown.
task: 1. Review the entire project. 2. Explore the git history with a focus on spikes and their outcomes. 3. Identify and articulate the learning story from the spikes. 4. Show how these spikes progress into a roadmap or potential areas to explore. 5. Update the root README to include progress and this learning/roadmap narrative.

steps.step1: Scan the entire repository: - Identify key directories, components, and existing documentation. - Note any existing references to spikes, experiments, or roadmap items.
steps.step2: Explore the git history: - Identify commits, branches, or tags corresponding to spikes and experiments. - Read commit messages (and PR descriptions, if available) to infer goals and outcomes of each spike.
steps.step3: Synthesize a learning story: - For each major spike, extract: its goal, what was tried, what was learned, and how it influenced later work. - Group related spikes into themes (e.g., architecture, integrations, performance, UX).
steps.step4: Derive roadmap and exploration areas: - Map spike outcomes to concrete roadmap items (features, refactors, integrations). - Identify open questions or unresolved findings as "potential areas to explore".
steps.step5: Design README updates: - Decide where in the root README to insert or update sections. - Plan sections such as: - "Current Project Status / Progress" - "Spike History & Learning Story" - "Roadmap & Potential Exploration Areas"
steps.step6: Edit the root README: - Preserve useful existing content (overview, setup, usage, etc.). - Add or update sections to: - Summarize progress to date. - Tell a coherent narrative of how spikes informed decisions. - Explicitly connect spike learnings to roadmap items and exploration areas.
steps.step7: Review and refine: - Ensure the README is self-contained and understandable to a new contributor. - Check that the spike-to-roadmap connections are explicit, not implied. - Verify formatting and structure follow Markdown best practices.

instructions: - Focus updates on the root README file. - Treat spikes as a chronological and thematic story that explains how the project evolved. - Make explicit links between: - Individual spikes → what was learned. - Learnings → decisions, architectural choices, and roadmap items. - Open questions → "potential areas to explore". - Use headings, subheadings, and bullet points to organize the narrative.
constraints: - Do not remove critical existing README information unless it is clearly obsolete or superseded. - Keep the README readable for both technical and semi-technical stakeholders. - Use Markdown formatting only. - Ensure the learning story is specific and grounded in spike work, not generic.
validation_rules: - The updated README must: - Contain a clear summary of **current project progress**. - Include a **"Spike History" or "Learning from Spikes"** section that references concrete spike work. - Explain **how spike learnings influenced the roadmap or key project decisions**. - List **future roadmap items and/or potential areas to explore** that are clearly traced back to spike outcomes or gaps. - Remain coherent and understandable without needing to read the git history directly. - The structure and headings must make it easy for a new contributor to: - Understand where the project is today. - See what experiments were run and why. - Know what is planned next or still uncertain.
output_format: - Provide the **full, updated root README content** as Markdown. - If helpful, precede it with a short summary of the main changes. - Optionally include a unified diff-style snippet (old vs new) only if it clarifies how the README evolved.
reasoning: - Silently perform multi-step reasoning: - Infer spike work and learnings from git history and code changes. - Group and prioritize spikes by impact on the project direction. - Translate technical details into a concise narrative suitable for the README. - Do not expose low-level reasoning steps in the final README text; present only the polished, user-facing documentation.
